title-group.article-title: Seasonality in the Returns of Defaulted Bonds: The January and October Effects

abstract.p: This paper addresses the issue of seasonality in the returns of defaulted corporate bonds. We find evidence of seasonality in monthly returns for January and October from 1970 to 1991. We find that returns in January are abnormally high, following the typical January effect found in small company stocks. We also find that returns in October are abnormally low. The results of our work are of direct interest and application to institutional managers who are investing in defaulted securities.
